newsitem.title: UK: LME lead shines on strong finish, just below $700.
newsitem.headline: LME lead shines on strong finish, just below $700.

text.p: Lead clung tightly to most of its gains on Friday from a blistering rally which propelled prices above $700 at one point.
Lead prices ended the London Metal Exchange (LME) afternoon kerb at $698 per tonne, a gain of $23 versus Thursday's finish.
Options related buying, fund shortcovering and tight April dates were responsible for the metal's dramatic surge which hit a high of $705 in the afternoon kerb, traders said.
Ahead of next Wednesday's options declaration, open interest was concentrated on $725 calls.
Cash to threes backwardation was at $20/$21 at the close, compared to level on Thursday, after April tightness emerged.
The market was also eyeing Friday's expiry of a labour contract at Canada's Noranda Brunswick lead/zinc mine and lead smelter for direction.
Other metals were largely softer, in part on end-of-month profit taking and book squaring.
Copper intially dipped to a low of $2,362, from Thursday's kerb close of $2,393, after LME stocks came in down an expected 3,475 tonnes.
But prices bounced up to finish the kerb at $2,378.
Aluminium was underpinned by a substantial LME stock decline of 11,075 tonnes on Friday morning.
However, it failed to move out of a narrow range and ended the kerb just $2 firmer at $1,654.
Nickel repeated Thursday's strong close of $8,070 against a backdrop of continued concerns about possible labour unrest in Russia's Norilsk Nickel factory.
Management and labour are due to meet on Saturday.
But Dresdner Kleinwort Benson said in a weekly report that expectations of a strike at Norilsk on March 15 may be exaggerated.
"...looming labour unrest in this sensitive industry in the past was usually prevented via successful negotiations," the bank said.
Zinc and tin fared less well than the other base metals.
Tin closed nearly $100 down at $5,790, compared to $5,880 on Thursday. A stocks rise of 170 tonnes did little to improve the market's sluggish tone.
Zinc held steady most of the day and made a halfhearted attempt to push higher at the afternoon kerb. But the effort fell flat and the metal finished at $1,218, down $9.
Alloy was last indicated at $1,540/45 versus $1,550.
--Lida Poletz, London newsroom +44 171 542 2936
